awd_titl_txt: CC* Compute:  GROWTH - Gateway for Increased Research Output at a West Texas Higher-education Campus
awd_abstract_narration:
West Texas A & M University (WTAMU) is expanding its computing resources to meet the rapidly growing needs of faculty, researchers, and students across four colleges on its campus. The university’s current objective is to attain doctoral status and become a Regional Research University to solve the complex and demanding problems associated with the Texas Panhandle region. This project is aimed at tackling the leading issues affecting the region: water and energy. The computing cluster enables scientific and engineering high performance computing (HPC) and data-intensive artificial intelligence (AI). These are key paradigms that are spearheading multiple science drivers across campus in water management, wind energy harvesting and energy storage. This program broadens and fortifies educational opportunities for a regional Hispanic Serving Institution with a recently established engineering graduate program, contributing to the development of an HPC & AI literate workforce. This cluster strongly impacts research and education communities associated with WTAMU, community colleges and industries in the Panhandle region, and Texas A&M Agrilife Research station in Amarillo. In addition to providing local computing resources, this cluster contributes towards the Open Science Grid, which provides high throughput computing resources across the nation. 

The compute cluster is equipped with 1024 compute CPU cores and 10240 GPU cores to enable massively parallel HPC workflows in computational fluid dynamics, computational materials science computational mechanics, machine learning and data visualization. It complements on campus materials characterization techniques via a computational-empirical interface and engages undergraduate and graduate students in high performance computing and big data applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
West Texas A&M University acquired its first ever high-performance compute cluster (WTAMU-HPC) to meet its growing computational needs as it strives to become a Regional Research University. This cluster has 832 CPU cores and 6 NVIDIA TESLA V100s GPUs and is connected via high speed networks to meet research and educational needs across the campus. INTELLECTUAL MERIT: This initiative has led the development of cyberinfrastructure (CI) (equipment and personnel) for computational and AI research for up to 17 campus users (7 faculty, 6 graduates, 2 undergraduates, 2 admin). It has enabled the development of a graduate course ‘High Performance Computing applications in Engineering’ which was administered to our Master of Engineering Students who completed projects (using finite element methods and molecular dynamics) using the HPC cluster. The cluster has shared computational resources (3.99 million CPU hours) towards national science drivers via the Open Science Grid and contributed 2.01 million CPU hours to campus science drivers, 1.52 million of which was carried out in 2023 indicating sharply increasing local utilization. This has assisted the work of 2 peer-reviewed publications and 1 publication under review. BROADER IMPACTS: This cluster has been utilized to deliver HPC workshops in two annual hackathons, which allowed students to learn about and execute parallel programs on the cluster. The positive momentum in computing created by the WTAMU-HPC has allowed the College of Engineering to develop a Human Machine Teaming (HMT) Laboratory that will be dedicated to exploring the intersection of human cognition and artificial intelligence. Specifically, the laboratory will focus on developing advanced technologies that allow humans and machines to work together more seamlessly, ultimately improving performance and efficiency across a wide range of research areas. In the HMT lab, faculty will conduct interdisciplinary research projects at the intersection of engineering, mathematics, computer science, and other fields to explore topics such as robotics, machine learning, artificial intelligence, computer vision, high performance computing, natural language processing, and human-computer interaction. This facility will also be used for educational purposes particularity intensive by the design/senior capstone courses in the engineering, math, and computer science curriculum. This laboratory will enable research projects aimed at developing innovative technologies that enable human-machine collaboration, including but not limited to (i) Intelligent decision support systems that help humans make more informed decisions by providing real-time feedback and guidance based on machine learning algorithms and artificial intelligence, (ii) virtual/augmented reality systems that enhance human perception and situational awareness by providing real-time data overlays and visualizations,  (iii) collaborative robotics systems that allow humans and robots to work together in close proximity, leveraging each other's strengths to perform complex tasks, (iv) big data analysis, (v) modeling and simulation of computational intensive engineering problems, and  (vi) natural language processing systems that enable humans to communicate more effectively with machines, reducing the need for complex programming or coding. In addition to these projects, the HMT Lab will also be used to conduct research and write research proposals that consider the ethical and societal implications of human-machine collaboration, exploring issues such as privacy, security, and trust in emerging technologies. Overall, the research/educational projects conducted at the Human Machine Teaming Laboratory has the potential to transform the educational experience offered to students by enabling humans and machines to work together more effectively and efficiently. The availability of this historic computational facility that was built through the CC* WTAMU-HPC has also been pivotal in attracting faculty and supporting student research grants.


Last Modified: 12/29/2023
Modified by: Anirban Pal
